name: The Causation Con
nickname: Just Because It's After Doesn't Mean It's Because
definition: Assuming that because one event followed another, the first event caused the second.
whyItWorks: Our brains love patterns. When something happens after something else, we assume the first thing caused it—even when lots of other stuff could explain it.

examples.text: I wore my lucky socks and we won the game. The socks definitely helped.
examples.analysis: Your team might have won because you practiced, the other team had an off day, or just luck. The socks just happened to be there.

examples.text: I started taking this supplement and felt better within a week. It definitely works!
examples.analysis: Could be placebo, other changes you made at the same time, or just naturally getting better anyway.

examples.text: Ever since we gave kids smartphones, teen anxiety has exploded. Phones are clearly the cause.
examples.analysis: Lots of other things changed too: school pressure, social expectations, the news. Timing alone doesn't prove phones are the main cause.

examples.text: Once my friend started hanging out with that new group, her grades dropped. Those friends ruined her grades.
examples.analysis: Maybe the work got harder, or she took on a job, or something else changed. New friends and lower grades happening together doesn't prove one caused the other.

examples.text: Crime dropped after we increased deportations. Proof that deportation reduces crime.
examples.analysis: Many factors affect crime: economy, policing, demographics. Things happening at the same time doesn't prove one caused the other.

examples.text: Since California reduced some sentences, crime increased. Soft-on-crime policies caused it.
examples.analysis: Lots changed at once: pandemic, economic stress, policing changes. You can't just pick one thing and blame it.

examples.text: Housing prices rose after remote work became common. Working from home caused the housing crisis.
examples.analysis: Many things happened at once: low interest rates, supply issues, investors buying houses. Remote work is just one piece.

examples.text: After more immigrants moved to the city, crime went up. Immigration caused the crime wave.
examples.analysis: Crime rates depend on many factors. A change after immigration doesn't prove immigrants are the cause.

examples.text: After that politician gave a fiery speech, political violence increased. The speech created the violence.
examples.analysis: You'd need careful evidence to show the speech caused specific attacks, not just that they happened in the same time window.

examples.text: We started talking more about cancel culture, and now people are more afraid to speak. The conversations caused the fear.
examples.analysis: People's fear could come from many sources: online pile-ons, workplace rules, news stories. Discussion alone isn't clear proof.

promptStarters: After ___ happened, ___ followed. Clearly, the first caused the second.
Ever since we started ___, we've seen ___. Coincidence?
The numbers don't lie: ___ went up/down right after ___.
We tried ___ and ___ got better. It obviously works.
Look at what happened after ___—the results speak for themselves.
